title: Inktraps in Serif Designs
content:
I was wondering if extreme inktraps, like the ones you find in certain designs like Amplitude of Bell Centennial, sometimes become a design element in serif typefaces. Does anybody know any typefaces which have them? Farnham has them to a certain extent, do you know of any others.

D.

 [‹ [people] Help the brother out](http://web.archive.org/web/20071111145647/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38823 "Go to previous forum topic") [Sterile type ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071111145647/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38944 "Go to next forum topic")
author: D. Wiewauters

comments.content: Exchange by Tobias Frere-Jones. And then there is this other one with enormous ink traps - Olga: [http://www.tdc.org/news/2007Results/Olga.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20071111145647/http:/www.tdc.org/news/2007Results/Olga.html "http://www.tdc.org/news/2007Results/Olga.html")

[Eason](http://web.archive.org/web/20071111145647/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/fountain/eason_osf_regular/?sample_text=bujnd&sample_size=144&acs_p=1&acs_pt=36&acs=1)’s serif connections could be considered ink traps.

Christian Robertson’s under construction Serif Beta contains robust ink traps in the Caption weight.  
The Betatype Beta Beta is available for free download at [www.betatype.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20071111145647/http:/www.betatype.com/ "www.betatype.com")
